TopicTitle: When did you buy KSP? (I want to know how many people waited for it to come out of Early Access)

Articles.Content: I bought it not too long before 23.5. Ah, good ol' ARM patch...
Before the great coffee spill of 2013!
Put 0.25, but actually was .22 when I first booted-up the game for the 1rst time.
.18 For me. Think it was when it just added to Steam.
It's clear to see, based on current poll results, that most people bought it when it first came out on Steam (which is also the time period I got it).
Way back in 0.16, after trying out the 0.13 demo version.
Man, I remember having to eyeball my Munar transfers. In those days, it was burn and hope.

> 
> They can take a LOT of abuse, generally speaking, before they blow up.

Sometimes. Kind of.

I was testing a fairly heavy lander once; nothing too crazy. It wasn't Whackjob proportions or anything, but it was big enough to satisfy a contract for a base with a capacity of 16 Kerbals, a science lab, etc. 

I slowly eased it up off the landing pad, juked it around a bit to make sure everything was working, and landed it back on the landing pad. It was sort of a hard landing, but not hard enough to break any of the landing legs.

The landing pad blew up underneath the lander. Lander was fine, but the landing pad went up in a ball of flame. ![:confused:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_huh.gif)

Bought it October 2012, after playing the 0.13 demo for over 100 hours. It was version 0.17, about a week before 0.18 came out.

I figured a game I put more hours into as a demo than some games I paid full price for deserved my money even if I never played it again. Since I migrated it to Steam when it first became available, I currently stand at 1032 hours. It has come a long way since that time.

Best $17 I ever spent on a game.

I gifted one copy that cost me $24, and it still feels like I massively underpaid for this game.

That's because currently building damage is calculated as a factor of mass and velocity, with no consideration of duration of impact (unsurprisingly; that sort of attention to detail is something that few games have). Meaning that a craft that weighs enough hitting the pad even at 2m/s can destroy it.
